headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: White House Braces for Midterm Losses; Ed Bastian is Interviewed about the Economy, Jobs and the Midterms. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Is going to join us next to react to what these voters are saying.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Van Jones.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Which race he thinks is going to determine how Democrats will do tomorrow night.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: This studio is not big enough for the both of us, Van Jones.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, President Biden has one last rally to go before the midterm elections as he is predicting that Democrats will keep the House and the Senate, but also warning it will be a horrible two years if they don't. That's a quote from President Biden over the weekend. Some Democrats fear that the party's messaging on the economy hasn't hit the mark though.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Joining us now is CNN political commentator Van Jones.Is Hilary Rosen right, that Democrats aren't listening to their voters?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Hi, Van. Good morning. Thanks - VAN JONES, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Don is our good morning reminder on this program.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I know. Good (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I hate when mommy and daddy are fighting.You know, Hilary Rosen is basically saying, you know --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, hey, listen, I think that there was a moment where it felt like, hey, maybe we could talk about abortion and democracy. It turns out that was fool's gold.When people are sitting on a white hot stove of economic pain, they want to know what you're going to do for them. I think the reality is, it's not over. People are going to be -- some people are making up their mind right now what to do. If -- what I think Democrats should be saying right now is, if you think it's bad now, wait until the Republicans jack up your prescription drug prices, wait until they hold the government hostage with the debt ceiling and take away Social Security and Medicare for your - for your grandma.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I don't - I - yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: If you think it's bad now, it could get worse, and will. And lean into the argument that the - that the actual economic proposals for the Republicans are terrible. We haven't done that yet, but people still got a long time to vote.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You -- wait, wait, wait, a long time to vote. It's tomorrow, man.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: That's a long time to vote. So, for the people, if you haven't voted, it's a long time.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I'm like -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Do you - do you think it's - do you think that is - there is time to pivot for --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes. Hey, listen, there are people right now who have not made up their mind. And I think that - we've got to - we've got the airwaves.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I'm telling you, if you think it's bad now, wait until your grandma has got to move in with you because Social Security and Medicare has been knocked out. Wait until you prescription drug prices go through the roof. Wait until your kid comes home from school not with a degree but with a baby because she can't get an abortion. You think it's bad now, it can get worse. That's what we should be talking about. LEMON

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes. Hey, listen, I don't - people have not voted. As - until the last person votes, we should be making the case. And I - and I think we should not have run from the economic argument. I think we should lean into it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Why didn't they make - I mean why -

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Because folks were scared.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Why didn't they make the case and say, these are the Republican senators who are, you know, wanting to vote every year, every five years on Medicare and Social Security? Why aren't they making the case, why aren't they talking more about infrastructure? I don't get it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Because folks were scared of talking about the economy, because people felt like, hey, if you talk about the economy, that's Republican. If you talk about crime, that's Republican. Let's talk about our own stuff.Now, that doesn't make sense now. But you can't blame people for hoping. But the reality is this, we have -- the Democratic Party has a lot to be proud of when it comes to 10 million jobs, a lot to be proud of when it comes to standing up to China on the Chips Act. There's a lot of -- infrastructure. We didn't lean in yet, but we should lean in today and tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Van's like, we've got a long time.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Just one more - one more thing before we - we were going to move on to another - but there is - so how do you balance that because there is truth about democracy. There's truth about abortion. There's a -

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Those are things that Democrats should be speaking of.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I agree. I agree with that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You have to - what's the balance here?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: And I'm tired of people being mad at Obama and Biden for speaking about democracy. When you're the head of state, you've got to tell people what they want to hear, and also what they need to hear. You can't be head of state or former president and not talk about (INAUDIBLE). That doesn't make any sense.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: One second. Let me just interrupt you a bit. If you look at what John Avlon just put up on the screen, you look at the election deniers around the country who could be - who could win -

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: It's a threat.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That is democracy on the ballot.Sorry, go on.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: That's the threat. And I think -- here's the thing, you can do both. And I think you should do both. I don't think it's right to tell the president of the United States not to defend democracy or to tell somebody like Obama, who's spent his whole life fighting for it, to shut up about it. That's not right. You've got to just do both. You go with both barrels. We went with one barrel.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: So, one thing that one Democrat wants President Biden not to talk about is a comment he made that kind of flew under the radar in California about coal plants.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. That one.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: We're going to be shutting these plants down all across America and having wind and solar.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Joe Manchin did not like that. He sent out a statement blasting Biden, notably in days before the midterm elections, and said that comment was, quote, not only outrageous and divorced from reality, it ignores the severe economic pain that the American people are feeling because of rising energy costs. The White House put out a statement saying, you know, if someone was basically offended by this, we didn't - we didn't mean that. What do you make of that?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Unforced error?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes, unforced error. I don't know why Biden said that. And the thing that people aren't thinking about is, the kind of coal that comes out of West Virginia is metallurgical coal. In other words, it's a coal that melts steel. What do you need steel for? The solar panel arrays. What do you need steel for? Wind turbines. What do you need steel for? Electric cars.So, Joe Manchin's coal is coal you need for the green revolution. Say that and don't say dumb stuff.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So then why aren't you out there - then who is advising people?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Van Jones, perhaps you should go back in your former role as a Democratic adviser. They need you.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Hey, listen, I'll answer the call.But, listen, there - we - I just hate when you do dumb stuff at the end, but I love this president.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right. JONES

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's fascinating to see a statement like that coming from Manchin just days before the election.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Totally.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I was told that the White House got a heads up that that was coming.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Van Jones -

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: As always, thank you for your insights.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Van.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Van.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I'm ready.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I'm ready.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right, coming up, companies across America are laying off workers as economic warnings get louder. What about the airline industry? How are they navigating it? Guess who is here in set - on set, in studio with us? Ed Bastian, the CEO of Delta.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I've got to talk about my miler status.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This is not about you.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right, more industries across the nation laying off workers as economic warnings get a lot louder. In just the past few days, look at those companies, tech companies including Twitter and Amazon. Some are just talking, I want to be clear, about hiring freezes, like Amazon and Microsoft. Others laying off a lot of workers.What about the airline industry, so hard hit during the pandemic, has really come back. So, let's talk about this and a lot more with the CEO of Delta Air Lines, Ed Bastian. Ed, good to have you.

utterances.speaker: ED BASTIAN, CEO, DELTA AIR LINES
utterances.sentences: Poppy, good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you for coming.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Congratulations on the new - the new show. This is awesome.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We're having a good time.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We are really are glad that you're here this morning.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, we're really - really glad you're on set.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you. I'm glad I'm here too.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: You know, the economy is in an unusual place. There are certain technology companies that are having some challenges. We're just the opposite. We're hiring and we're still hiring a lot. We've hired 25,000 people since the start of last year, and we're continuing to hire because the demand for the service economy has been suppressed the last couple of years. People can't go places. You know, they have stuff all over the place and they don't want any more stuff, which I think is hurting certain retailers. But if you're in the experience sector, if you're in travel, hospitality, restaurants, entertainment, it's off the charts.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Are you having a hard time finding people?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: We're really not, Don. The value of running a great company with a great brand, people want to come. And they realize there's -- this is like a once-in-a-generation opportunity to get inside a high - because we usually only hire 3,000 or 4,000 people a year. And so hiring 25,000 is unreal.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So does that mean - I mean so many big name CEOs, especially ones who are pretty good about predicting where this economy is going, are really worried. I mean Jamie Dimon, JP Morgan, just a few weeks ago said it's likely the U.S. will fall into recession in the next six to nine months. Do you agree with him?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: It could. I think there's likely that we're going to see a soft patch. Whether it's hard landing or a soft landing, I don't know. But what we're seeing is we're in a counter cyclical - you know, because we've had a recession the last two years. I mean our business was cut off at the knees. And so if you're in the service sector, you're actually looking to grow and continue to grow. Delta, we expect to grow probably about 15 percent between now and next year.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And what is the question when it comes to what that recession could potentially look like? Because this is a conversation, you know, we have with White House officials all the time.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You know, they say, we're not preparing for one, we're not having meetings, acting like there's going to be one, but it makes a difference what kind of recession it could potentially be. So, how does that affect your planning?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Well, again, our planning is probably a little bit, again, recession-proof because we're -- we're down about 15 percent from where we should be already. So, we're not having that. Companies, business travel is usually where we get impacted the most. Business travel is already down from historical levels, so there's really nothing to cut. In fact, businesses need to be out with their customers. As I tell CEOs, if you're not out with your customers right now because everybody's traveling, somebody else is.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So - so -

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: And so there's a - there - you know, there's countercyclical effects here that are happening. It's going to be interesting to watch.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You are, though, dealing with potentially down the road a pilot strike. You've got 96 percent of your pilots voted and 99 percent of those said that they would strike if you guys can't work out the contract negotiations, OK. They watch you guys making a lot of money after the pandemic and they say you've rebounded, you're stronger than ever. You know, and their -- their quote, the ball is in management's court to get this deal done.Should people worry about a strike?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Absolutely not. First of all, it would be illegal to have a strike anytime soon.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Because there's a cooling off, mediation period --

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: There's - there's -- we're making great progress at the table. This is a tactic that all the unions, the airline unions, have gone though. The pilots at the other properties have done the same thing. It's really trying to drive some attention at the issue. We're already at the table trying to work out a deal.The Delta pilots are the best paid in the industry. They are -- and they deserve to be such. They will be the best paid coming through this. So, I think this is a normal step. But there's quite a few stages that have to go before a federal mediator and then a presidential emergency board would approve the strike. So, we're nowhere close. And, by the way, they don't want a strike. We don't want a strike. It's not going to happen.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Are you the largest employer in Georgia?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Georgia, yes.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: I think we are.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So - and our company is based in Georgia. So, as you know, we use Delta a lot. And being on your airline, I notice that you have a very diverse workforce.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Georgia's been the center of politics for the last couple of years. You have not been afraid to speak out on issues as it relates to -- and standing up for your employees.How do you feel about CEOs doing that about - because there are - there is a belief that CEOs should not weigh in on this and it should be sort of non-partisan. But do you think it's important to stand up for your diverse workforce? (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: I think when you see something happening in the world that runs counter to your values, runs against really the interest of your business and your people, you have to ask yourself the question, how do you engage? And sometimes you have to speak up. Candidly, Don, we've all been trained growing up in this business not to speak up. You don't want to see your face on the news or whatnot. And you want all -- everybody to love you, not just your customers. You want to try to be a good - a good citizen. But there's sometimes where you have to speak and -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: How do you feel about the criticism to that? Because you - you know, it's got - it's got to be tough for you. And does it affect your business? Do you see an impact?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: I would say that the times I've spoken, and there's been a couple times.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, you took on the NRA. You spoke out on the Georgia voting bill.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Do you think that's part of the reason that you are having success? I mean, obviously, the people are spending money. Even the possibility of a recession. People are still spending money on travel.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Do you think it's part of the reason for your success, because you stand up for the values of your employees and what you believe in?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: I think people love the brand. They primarily love our people. And it's the people that make the difference in our business, in the airline business. It's a service business.And so we -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So what's the lesson or other people? You say people love your brand. And if you were not true to your brand, we've seen people and companies who are not true to their brand and they lose their loyal customers, they lose their fans.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Their fan base.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. And we're -- and we carry 200 million people a year. So, we have a large international fan base, if you think about it. But if you're out there and you're talking and speaking to your customers and your people about what you are for, rather than what you are against, when something happens, you know, you get into trouble when people are surprised. They say, where did that come from? That's when trouble hits. But if there's something that's consistent with what you talk about -- so you're always trying to play offense in this area, always talk about what you're for so that people won't be surprised about what you -- who you are when you have to speak.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And, of course, all this factors into your day to day decisions. I know one question that people have had about the industry is, when do you think it's going to be back to 2019 flight levels, and does that factor into Delta adding more flights going through Atlanta, because one big concern that people have had is affordability because prices have skyrocketed.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It's expensive.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. COLLINS

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean look at - look at -- the numbers are up on the screen now.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: There are three things. First of all, the demand is already back. The raw demand. You know, the interest in travel. And you can see that. Everyone felt once the pandemic subsided they needed to go someplace. And, by the way, whatever price it took, they were - they were just - they needed to get out. So, the demand is driving the principle factor in pricing.Fuel prices. Our fuel prices are up 50 percent above where they were in 2019.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: That's our single biggest cost. It's not even people, it's fuel prices. That also has to be covered in the pricing.And the third thing is that we're not all the way back yet. So, we're going to grow 15 percent between now and next summer and a lot of that growth is going into Atlanta. And so that's going to take some of the pressure off pricing to bring all the routes back (INAUDIBLE). But we don't want to grow until we have the resources capable of handling that high demand.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It -- and part of the reason flights are really expensive also is this, there's less capacity, right, but that's very frustrating when you're on planes and you feel like they're very full and it costs a lot.This summer, I just want to reflect, if you could, on this summer, the flight woes, what Americans went through on travel, the back and forth between you guys and the Biden administration, Secretary Buttigieg namely. What's the lesson from all of that and are we past it for good do you think?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure there's a real lesson. I mean you -- we're overcoming a pandemic.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: We started the year with omicron, right, the first couple months of the year.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. BASTIAN

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You kept your middle seats empty I think longer than anyone.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: We did. We did.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You hired a chief medical officer.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But you're having the same -- it's the same issue for you as for oil companies.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You see oil companies - Americans see oil companies - the prices of gas going up and they see oil companies making record profits. They see airline prices going up but yet they see you on here saying, we're doing well.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So -

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: We're doing well on revenue. We're not - we're not anywhere close to record profits, I just want to be clear on that. We're - we're down meaningfully in terms of profits because we don't have our full demand set back in terms of the utilization of the aircraft and fuel prices are really, really high.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So talk about possible inflation. Is that hurting you at all? Do you think it - do you think it hurts or helps?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: On the - on the margin. On the margin. The thing with inflation is also -- there's currency effects. And so the other thing we're seeing is we're seeing more demand to Europe than ever before.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Did I say inflation? I meant possible recession. Sorry, go on. But the possibility of a recession, is that - you know, is that --

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Well, I think -- again, I think it's more of a business traveler that would be mindful of that, but business travel is already down. The other thing with the recession is that typically when recessions hit, oil prices start to subside.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: And so we're a bit hedged for that.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Quickly, can we ask you about seat sizes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Kaitlan wants to know. COLLINSbecause they feel like the seats are getting smaller.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Sure. They should.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I know you said Delta has not made their seats smaller.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The FAA, you believe this is ultimately up to them, you know, should they regulate the seat sizes though?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Well, the FAA already tests seat sizes and they test, you know, compliance. Anytime you change anything on aircraft, the FAA has to approve it.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: One of the real lessons of people value their experience on our brand.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: And so they're willing - and, by the way, they're willing to pay a premium for that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Did you think you'd be able to get out of -- when you were leading during Covid, I know there were days when you were wondering what is going to happen here. Did you think you'd be sitting here and the company would be where it is today after all that?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: I was confident we'd get there. We came back a little sooner than I thought.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Ed Bastian -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I've got to tell you that -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We've got - we've got to go -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That - that - yes, we've got to go because Poppy - and, well, Kaitlan mostly, I know you're a big Georgia fan. BASTIAN

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, thank you, Ed Bastian. We appreciate you joining us.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Ed, very much.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thanks so much.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But this is why Kaitlan doesn't want to talk about what's happened. She keeps asking the CEO questions. So, sorry, Kaitlan, it is time to gloat. My LSU Tigers beat Kaitlan's Alabama Crimson Tide this weekend in an overtime thriller.Kaitlan, the jersey is waiting for you. LSU jersey.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I won't be wearing a jersey. If you need to go to commercial, feel free.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I'm just staying out of this.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Kaitlan --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Sorry, I'm reading Twitter.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Here you go, Kaitlan. What happened this weekend? Do you - which jersey - do you want to wear the jersey or the hat?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You know, it says a lot about how you act when you win.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) - I did not gloat.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Gloating. Gloating.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I did not gloat when we beat --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Don called me within 30 seconds of the end of the game.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Did I gloat?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it was a little bit of gloating.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: He sent a video, too.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You know what - you know what, the play calling was not great. You know, it was a struggle for Alabama. And I hated --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, you guys had referees on your team. You had extra men on the field.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).
